perturbation.original_text:
17.
DURATION OF THE AGREEMENT

17.1
This Agreement shall come into force on the Date of the Agreement, and shall, subject to article 18, remain in full force and effect for an initial period of *** from the Commercial Launch Date.
17.2
The Agreement may be terminated by both Parties with a notification period of *** before the end of the Initial Term of the Agreement. If no termination notice is provided, the Agreement will be automatically extended for consecutive *** periods until such time as *** termination notice is provided. At the end of *** Parties will negotiate in good faith regarding a possible extension of the Initial Term.

Parties can mutually agree in writing to deviate from an automatic extension of *** by extending this Agreement for a longer period than
***.
perturbation.changed_text:
17.
DURATION OF THE AGREEMENT

17.1
This Agreement shall come into force on the Date of the Agreement, and shall, subject to article 18, remain in full force and effect for an initial period of *** from the Commercial Launch Date. After the initial period, the agreement may or may not be extended.
17.2
The Agreement may be terminated by either Parties at any point, or it may continue indefinitely, subject to negotiations and agreement. If no termination notice is provided, the Agreement will be evaluated, and there is no guarantee of extension. At the end of *** Parties will consider, but are not obligated, to negotiate in good faith regarding a possible extension of the Initial Term.

Parties can mutually agree in writing to deviate from an automatic extension of *** by extending this Agreement for a shorter or longer period than
***.
perturbation.explanation: The original text implies an automatic renewal with a specific notification period. The modified version contradicts this by stating that extension is not guaranteed and termination is possible at any point, thus creating uncertainty about the agreement's duration and renewal conditions.

perturbation.original_text:
1.26
“Quarter” and “Quarterly” shall mean a quarter of a year, being three consecutive months starting every January, April, July and/or
October of every calendar year.
1.27
“Ready for Service Date” shall mean the date, following the Soft Launch, upon which the Hosting Services agreed between the Parties - in
accordance with article 3 - meet the agreed specification as evidenced by the signing of the Protocol for Delivery.
perturbation.changed_text:
1.26
“Quarter” and “Quarterly” may mean any duration the Parties agree to deem a fiscal period, such agreement at the sole discretion of T-Mobile, to be updated and revised accordingly in the operational manual.
1.27
“Ready for Service Date” shall mean a date, subject to revisions, following a possible Soft Launch. At the discretion of T-Mobile, the agreed upon hosting services will meet agreed specifications, as evidenced by the signing, if applicable, of a Protocol for Delivery.
perturbation.explanation: The original text provides a clear definition for 'Quarter' and 'Ready for Service Date'. The modified version introduces ambiguity by stating that 'Quarter' may mean any duration agreed upon and making the meeting of specifications for the 'Ready for Service Date' subject to T-Mobile's discretion, effectively contradicting the original specific definitions and creating uncertainty.

perturbation.original_text:
11.
CONFIDENTIALITY
11.1
The Parties agree that all aspects of the content of this Agreement shall be treated as confidential and that no information in respect of the
content and/or existence of this Agreement shall be disclosed without the prior written consent of both Parties. Neither Party shall make
any public announcements, including but not limited to press releases, articles, brochures, advertisements and speeches, concerning this
Agreement without the prior written consent of the other Party. However, ELEPHANT TALK is entitled to communicate - as far as strictly
necessary for the proper conclusion of its agreements- to the ELEPHANT TALK Customer that its services are provided by (the) T-Mobile
(network). ELEPHANT TALK Customers shall be entitled to communicate that the network coverage is provided by T-Mobile, only in case
they are asked for it. Under no circumstances, ELEPHANT TALK Customers shall make any public announcements, including but not
limited to press releases, commercial articles (not being technical or business articles), brochures, advertisements, public speeches and
other promotional material, that its services to mobile end-users are provided by the T-Mobile network.
perturbation.changed_text:
11.
CONFIDENTIALITY
11.1
The Parties agree that all aspects of the content of this Agreement shall be treated as confidential, except when business needs require it or if directed by a third-party client. Information in respect of the
content and/or existence of this Agreement may be disclosed at T-Mobile's discretion, without needing the prior written consent of both Parties. T-Mobile may make
any public announcements, including but not limited to press releases, articles, brochures, advertisements and speeches, concerning this
Agreement without the prior written consent of the other Party. However, ELEPHANT TALK is entitled to communicate - as far as strictly
necessary for the proper conclusion of its agreements- to the ELEPHANT TALK Customer that its services are provided by (the) T-Mobile
(network). ELEPHANT TALK Customers shall be entitled to communicate that the network coverage is provided by T-Mobile, only in case
they are asked for it. Under any circumstances, ELEPHANT TALK Customers can decide to publicly release announcements. T-Mobile also retains right to all marketing materials created with this information.
perturbation.explanation: The original text mandates strict confidentiality, requiring prior written consent for any disclosure. The modified version contradicts this by allowing T-Mobile to disclose information at its discretion and gives customers the right to publicity. This undermines the confidentiality clause, creating uncertainty about which information is protected and who has the right to disclose it.
